A personal View on the Creation vs. Evolution argument. The more DNA research that is completed, the more confusion about DNA and the unanswered questions of that 75% of so-called junk DNA arises. Mitochondrial DNA, the Human Genome, and the debatable existence of transitional fossils (depends on what scientist your talking to) all raise questions there really are no answers for----just hypothesis and theory.
 
 Is there such a thing as Micro-Evolution? Hell yeah, I have witnessed it in my lifetime----children are growing bigger and stronger than ever before, and whether it is because of nutrition and better medicinal care does nor matter----it's Micro-Evolution none-the-less. Many equate the evolutionary theory with a tornado striking a junk yard, pulling some car parts into its vortex, and laying down a perfectly assembled car in a parking lot five miles away. 2nd Law of thermodynamics say's this cannot happen, yet that is the evolutionary theory.
 
 Scientists cannot even get together on the dates modern Homo Sapien first walked the earth. Seemingly, every year there is some form of new fossil discovered, raising even more questions about the mass diaspora of population out of Africa. How many species co-existed at the same time? Which one was the true species in the human evolutionary change?
 
 Many people point to the Chimp and Bobo as being the closest related mammal to humans on the planet. Scientist's claim anwhere from 98%-99% similarities in our Genomes----well, that's only about 40 Billion gene sequences that are different. And, if we are related to the Chimp, why didn't they evolve? Nope, I certainly do not believe God put Adam & Eve down here on the Planet 6000 years ago, but I cannot say I am confident in the evolutionary research up to this point either.
 
 Boils down to this; I have a ton of questions, but I do not have any answers. To believe Human life started approximately 6000 years ago is totally naive, but asking me to believe I come from a chimp seems no less ridiculous to me. To believe in evolution we have to believe that life was triggered by some form of prebiotic soup filled with enzymes, protiens, ammino acids, etc. In this modern day and age, no scientist as of yet has ever been able to prove the prebiotic soup theory---so technically, the Macro-Evolutionary theory, is just that----A highly educated guess and still just a theory.

 Well, that shows a lot of ignorance about what a scientific theory is, and what evolutionary theory is. Evolutionary theory does not say that man came from a chimp, it says that man and chimp come from a common ancestor.. 
 
 You are also mixing up the hypothesis of abiogensis with the theory of evolution. Work on how life was formed from non-life is still in it's infancy, but much further along that Creationists ever dreamed possible. As for the 'prebiotic soup', why, just look at the latest observations from Titan. They found that there are complex organic compounds in the atmosphere of Titan, something they did not expect. That very strongly reinforces the idea that there was a 'prebiotic' soup on earth 3 billion years ago. 
 
 There is a difference between 'biological evolution' and the theory of evolution. A theory is a model that trys to explain why things happen. Evolution, including the so-called 'macro' evolution has been observed in nature. The theory of evolution is a model on trying to figure out WHY it happens. So far, after 150 years of intense trying, it has not been able to be falsified.

 Here's the theory as I understand it in a very quick nutshell
 
 1. Approx 70 Million y/a during the Cretaceous Period, Promisians and Primate Stock originated
 
 2. Approx 20-30 Million y/a the so-called split from our common ancestor ocurred during the Oligocene Period.
 
 3. This split in the Primate Stock went in three directions, Old World Monkeys, New World Monkeys, and Homonoids
 
 4. Approximately 10 ya the Orangutan went its separate way in the Miocene Period, the Gorrila went off on its own at the edge of the Miocene leading into the Pliocene Period.
 
 5. Approximately 5mya Humans  developed and around 1.7mya Chimps and Bonobos split, making the Bonobo the closest relative to Human on the planet as it relates to DNA. This change ocurred as the Pliocene moved into the Pliestocene all the way to the present.

The Theory of Human Evolution by the numbers. 
 
 1. Scientists argue humans originated somewhere between 4-5 mya in the form of Ardipithecus & Australlopithicus. Ardipithicus dies out almost immediately and no one knows why.
 
 2. Around 2.75 mya, Paranthropus and Early Homo man allegedly split from Australopithicus, even though Australopthicus co-existed with both for approximately 700,000 more years.
 
 3. Approximately 1.75 mya, Early Homo man  started splitting into different species. At one point, even though we allegedly evolved from Australopithicus, Early Homo Man, Homo Erectus, and Parathropus , they all co-existed.
 
 4. The early splits in Homo Man that lead to Homo Erectus have allegedly led to the split into Archaic Homo Sapiens, which then leads to Modern Homo sapiens somewhere approximately 240,000 - 300,000 years ago.
 
 5. Homo Erectus did not die out until a little less than 100,000 y/a, Archaic Homo Sapiens died out a little over 100,000 y/a, and Modern Homo Sapien co-existed with both.
 
 How did we do all this evolving if we were co-existing?

 Junk DNA isn't really, and isn't called that by molecular genetists - its just non-coding DNA. Lot of it is parts of genes that have been copied but not completely, other bits are promoters and recongition sites for things that will govern how much of the gene is produced and under what conditions.
 Other bits are latent viruses that have inserted their code into our genome but then left it to us to replicate it and not bother with the making more viruses bit. These have also been randomly cut up and repeated as well.
 
 They have mapped the human genome - but this has nothing to do with knowing what the various genes do. Essentially we have just copied the book out and made note of the paragraphs. We haven't got round to reading any of them, just noted where the paragraphs are so we can put them in the index. Others of the 'new genes' that are found (rather than the purpose for a gene that we knew about) are new alleles, a new version of a gene we know about that has some new and interesting property. Others genuinely are new genes because they are coming out of some other speicies.

The temperature, salinity and depth of the Chalk Sea
 
 The fossil content of the Chalk of NW Europe, particularly the abundance and diversity of the planktonic foraminifer and coccoliths indicates tropical water temperatures of 20 0C or more. This has been confirmed by oxygen isotope analysis.
 
 Normal marine salinities are indicated by the fossil assemblage which comprises a normal marine assemblage which does not include species thought to be representative of lower salinity environments such as estuaries.
 
 The Chalk of NW Europe was deposited on the continental shelf during the earliest stages of the opening of the Atlantic Ocean (Biscay to Labradore opening at the beginning of Chalk deposition) . The sea level was much higher than the present day with the Chalk of Kent typically being deposited in a depth range of 100-300m. The sea levels varied through its deposition. However, not all Chalk was deposited at this depth with some marginal (shallow) marine deposits being recorded both in Devon and NW France.
 
 The Chalk often shows a distinctive cyclicity (on a 1m or so scale) which has been linked to variation in the climate at the time of deposition (Milankovitch cycles).
 
 The lack of coarser clastic material in the majority of the Chalk, with quartz being most common in the clay size grade, indicates clear seas with minimal eroded products being transported from the landmasses at the time. Indeed, much of the clay sized quartz and clay may be airborn and of volcanic origin.

 occam's razor-
 
 <philosophy< The English philosopher, William of Occam
 (1300-1349) propounded Occam's Razor:
 
 Entia non sunt multiplicanda praeter necessitatem.
 
 (Latin for "Entities should not be multiplied more than
 necessary"). That is, the fewer assumptions an explanation of
 a phenomenon depends on, the better it is.
 
 For example, some claim that God caused himself to exist and
 also caused the universe to exist - he was the "first cause" -
 whereas Occam's Razor suggests that if one accepts the
 possibility of something causing itself then it is better to
 assume that it was the universe that caused itself rather than
 God because this explanation involves fewer entities.
 
 The negation of Occam's Razor would suggest that an
 arbitrarily complex explanation is just as good as the
 simplest one. (E.g. God and his cat created a robot called
 Sparky who built the universe from parts bought from a shop in
 another dimension).
 
 dictionary.com
